findings.title: A.1 Approve Race
findings.description: The standard ERC20 implementation contains a widely-known racing condition in its approve function, wherein a spender is able to witness the token owner broadcast a transaction altering their approval and quickly sign and broadcast a transaction using transferFrom to move the current approved amount from the owner’s balance to the spender.

findings.title: Renounce Ownership
findings.description: The renounceOwnership function can be used to renounce ownership without transferring it to a different address, which is risky.

findings.title: B.1 Missing Value Verification
findings.description: Certain functions lack a safety check in the values, the values of the arguments should include some safety checks test, otherwise, the contract's functionality may get hurt.

findings.title: B.2 Renounce Ownership
findings.description: The renounceOwnership function can be used to renounce ownership without transferring it to a different address, which is risky.

findings.title: B.3 Usage Of block.timestamp
findings.description: The usage of block.timestamp can introduce uncertainty and potential security risks due to its reliance on the timestamp of the previous block.

findings.title: C.1 Missing Value Verification
findings.description: Certain functions lack a safety check in the values; the values of the arguments should include some safety checks, otherwise, the contract's functionality may get hurt.

findings.title: C.2 Renounce Ownership
findings.description: The renounceOwnership function can be used to renounce ownership, but if the contract's ownership has not been transferred previously, it will never have an Owner, which is risky.

findings.title: C.3 Usage Of block.timestamp
findings.description: The usage of block.timestamp can introduce a time delay of up to 900 seconds which may affect the logic of the staking contract.
